entry.title: New â€˜dragon princeâ€™ dinosaur is missing ancestor of T. Rex
entry.summary: This illustration depicts how the slender Khankhuuluu mongoliensis may have appeared as it roamed Mongolia during the Cretaceous period. The newest addition to the tyrannosaur family, the discovery of this "dragon prince from Mongolia" sheds light on the origins of Tyrannosaurus rex. Khankhuuluu mongoliensis was slender with features like no other member of the tyrannosaur family tree. Tyrannosaurus rex is a carnivorous icon. Exceeding 40 feet in length and nine tons, the bone-crushing giant stands out as the largest and last of its meat-eating family. Now a new and far smaller tyrannosaur is filling in the famous dinosaurâ€™s evolutionary bâ€¦

entry.title: How Alexander the Great's daddy issues reshaped the world
entry.summary:
Alexander the Greatâ€™s childhood has often been presented as a time of conflict between his parents, Philip II and Olympias. But this image, so often explored in novels and films, is likely exaggerated. Most of the sources preserved from this period are Athenian; no Macedonian writings have survived. So it was Philipâ€™s enemies, with their subjective and even manipulated accounts, who shaped what we know about the intricacies of the Macedonian court. Nevertheless, dynastic tensions evidently ran high at the court of Philip, and one factor that had an impact on family relations was the practice of polygamy.
Marriage in Macedonia was a politically oriented institution, often used to establish diplomatic relations or ensure royal succession. Philip had seven wives but among them they bore â€¦

entry.title: A travelerâ€™s guide to the east side of Vancouver Island
entry.summary:
The east side of Vancouver Island is ideal for adventurous travelers, with mountains, forests, oceans, and rivers. From world-class whale watching to oysters shucked at their source, there is a fascinating mix of culture, wildlife, and cuisine on the eastern coastline of British Columbiaâ€™s largest island.
When people think about Vancouver Islandâ€”the largest island on North Americaâ€™s west coast and just 60 miles west of Vancouverâ€”they may picture the cosmopolitan capital of Victoria in the South Island, or perhaps its ancient forests, home to some of the tallest trees on Earth. But the islandâ€™s eastern coastline, from Nanaimo up to Port Hardy, offers a glimpse into an even quieter way of life, where you can stroll one of the windswept beaches, go on a world-class whale watching expeâ€¦

entry.title: Inside the foundry forging $15,000 artisanal samurai swords
entry.summary: At Nippon Genshosha, a sword workshop on Japanâ€™s Tango Peninsula, Tomoyuki Miyagi (left), Tomoki Kuromoto (center), and Kosuke Yamazoe (right) work together to hammer, heat, and fold a piece of steel. The process, called tanren, strengthens the metal. It can take more than a year to make a single razor-sharp katana. In Japan, business is booming for the few remaining smiths who know how to do it. In a converted barnÂ on a residential lane on Japanâ€™s Tango Peninsula, some 75 miles north of Kyoto, three men are playing with fire. While robust flames lick the edges of a 2300-degree furnace, Kosuke Yamazoe uses a 15-pound hammer on a mass of white-hot steel, flattening it beat by beat in a hypnotic rhythm. Behind the shower of embers raining down on the earthen floor, Tomoyuâ€¦

entry.title: This Basque city is known for pintxosâ€”and it's not San Sebastian
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Sitting at the smart, horseshoe bar of El ToloÃ±o, veteran head chef Josu ArmiÃ±o is letting me into a secret. â€œWeâ€™ve got something that I think other places donâ€™t have, and thatâ€™s the simplicity of the way we use ingredients,â€ he says, sporting pristine chefâ€™s whites and a slightly mischievous smile. â€œFor me, the most important thing is the quality of the produce we have here.â€
In the Basque capital of Vitoria-Gasteiz, El ToloÃ±o is one of the most locally revered pintxos bars â€” and for good reason. â€œItâ€™s not about creating things with foams and all that,â€ Josu goes on to explain. â€œItâ€™s about simplicity and building on the traditions of our grandparentsâ€™ cooking,â€ he says. â€œWe add a touch of glamour and a bit more waâ€¦

entry.title: Your breathing pattern is unique like your fingerprint
entry.summary:
Colored 3D computed tomography (CT) scan of the spaces within the facial bones surrounding the nasal cavity. In a new study, scientists identified people based only on their breathing pattern with almost 97 percent accuracyâ€”and soon might be able to analyze yours to diagnose what ails you.
Everyoneâ€™s breathing pattern is unique, and soon scientists might be able to analyze yours to diagnose what ails you.
Scientists were able to identify individual people based just on their breathing pattern with 96.8 percent accuracy, and different patterns corresponded to differences in physical and mental traits, according to a new study in Current Biology.
Because it happens subconsciously, breathing may seem simple, but itâ€™s controlled by a complex brain network.Â
â€œRespiration â€¦

entry.title: Free Asha. Or cage her?
entry.summary:
Asha is circling the perimeter of her pen. Sheâ€™s pacing, moving with that long, rangy gait that all Mexican gray wolves have, her body graceful and liquid, motions smooth and purposeful. She stalks around jagged rocks, behind juniper bushes and yucca plants. She runs from the humans in her pen, anxious and hyperaware. For my part, Iâ€™m awestruck. This is the closest Iâ€™ve been to a wolf, and Iâ€™m only able to see her because she is currently being held in captivity by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) in the Sevilleta Wolf Management Facility near Socorro, New Mexico.
Asha has been ensnared; and like so many humans invested in her, so have I.Â
The four-year-old she-wolf has been placed in the facility because she refuses to stay put, repeatedly crossing into territory offâ€¦

entry.title: Where to find the perfect gelato in Rome
entry.summary:
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
Thereâ€™s never a wrong time for gelato in Rome. But nothing beats the sensation of cooling down with a deliciously fresh scoop on a hot summer day. With hundreds of gelaterie (ice cream parlours) across the Eternal City, the challenge isnâ€™t finding gelato, itâ€™s finding the best one. But what, exactly, is gelato?
This is one of the most common questions people ask when visiting Rome, and while both ice cream and gelato are beloved frozen treats, the difference between the two lies in the ingredients, texture and how theyâ€™re served. Gelato contains more milk and less cream than ice cream, resulting in a lower fat content, which some people find easier to digest. Itâ€™s churned at a slower speed, incorporating less air, â€¦

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 160 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Centerâ€™s nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted Jan. 8-19, 2025, among a sample of lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and queer (LGBTQ) U.S. adults. A total of [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Rising Number of U.S. Households Are Headed by Married Same-Sex Couples
entry.summary: The number of households headed by same-sex couples in the U.S. has risen steadily, but they represent a small share of all married couples. The post Rising Number of U.S. Households Are Headed by Married Same-Sex Couples appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Same-Sex Parents Raising Kids

entry.title: UN General Assembly adopts Gaza ceasefire resolution by overwhelming majority
entry.summary: Meeting in emergency session on Thursday in New York, the UN General Assembly overwhelmingly adopted a resolution demanding an immediate, unconditional and lasting ceasefire in Gaza.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: â€˜Indifference and impunityâ€™ in Sudan, ICC judges speak out against sanctions, respiratory diseases overlooked in Europe
entry.summary: With over half of the Sudanese population in need of aid and lean season rapidly approaching, theÂ UN Chief for Humanitarian Affairs once againÂ sounded the alarm about the crisis unfolding in Sudan on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN chief â€˜deeply saddenedâ€™ as Air India crash claims lives of over 200 on board
entry.summary: A London-bound Air India jet carrying 242 people crashed moments after take-off from Ahmedabad on Thursday, reportedly killing more than 200 on board, with dozens still unaccounted for.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Yemen at breaking point as UN envoy urges action to end suffering
entry.summary: Yemen cannot endure more years of division, economic collapse and human suffering, the UNâ€™s top official on the crisis told the Security Council on Thursday, warning that â€œtime is not on our side.â€

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Famine stalks two counties in South Sudan as fragile peace is threatened
entry.summary: Two counties in the Upper Nile State of South Sudan are sliding into famine, the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) warned in a new report released Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜No Ocean Declaration without small islandsâ€™: Delegates push for inclusion as UN summit nears end
entry.summary: With one day remaining before the conclusion of the Third UN Ocean Conference, delegates in Nice are preparing for the adoption of the summitâ€™s eagerly anticipated political declaration. Small island developing States, facing the direct effects of climate change and marine resource decline, are pushing to ensure their perspectives are reflected in global ocean policy.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Global push to end plastic pollution gains ground in Nice
entry.summary: Behind closed doors, in a domed conference pavilion steps away from the historic port of Nice, more than 40 ministers gathered on Tuesday to tackle one of the planetâ€™s fastest-growing environmental threats: plastic pollution.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Decades of memories and loss â€“ searching for the missing in Syria
entry.summary: Tens of thousands of people went missing in Syria over the past 50 years including during 14 years of civil war. Now, some families are able to live in hope as the Middle Eastern country emerges from the traumatic period of dictatorship and conflict.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: GAZA LIVE: UN General Assembly to vote on resolution demanding immediate, unconditional and permanent ceasefire
entry.summary: The General Assembly meets at 3pm in New York on Thursday in emergency session following the Security Councilâ€™s failure to adopt a resolution on 4 June calling for an immediate and permanent ceasefire in Gaza, which was vetoed by permanent member the United States. As starvation looms across the Strip, mass casualties continue to be reported of desperate civilians trying to access food at Israel and US-backed distribution sites. App users can follow our live coverage here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Atomic watchdog says Iran not complying with nuclear safeguards
entry.summary: The UN-backed atomic watchdog voted through a resolution on Thursday declaring that Iran is not complying with its obligations regarding nuclear non-proliferation.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Displacement doubles while funding shrinks, warns UNHCR
entry.summary: With 13.5 million people displaced by over 13 years of brutal civil conflict, Syria used to represent the largest displacement crisis in the world. This is no longer the case.

entry.title: These U.S. national sites honor the milestones of LGBTQ+ heritage
entry.summary:
In the Greenwich Village neighborhood of New York City, the Gay Liberation Monument in Christopher Park near the Stonewall Inn pays homage to the historically pivotal Stonewall Rebellion, which included prominent gay rights activists including Marsha P. Johnson and Sylvia Rivera. See the countryâ€™s past through a distinctly queer lens at these National Park Service-managed destinations.
Just as it turned 100 in 2016, Americaâ€™s National Park Service (NPS) began to officially recognize the contributions that LGBTQ+ Americans have made to the rich and diverse history of the United States.
Given the groundbreaking importance of New York Cityâ€™s Stonewall Inn to global queer history, the National Park Service (NPS) Â fittingly named New York Cityâ€™s Stonewall National Monument as its fâ€¦

entry.title: Not everyone should be taking a multivitamin
entry.summary:
Though multivitamins provide a tempting solution, the best way to get the nutrients your body needs is through good food, like broccoli. In some situations, they can be helpful. In others, they can lead to dangerous nutrient deficiencies or imbalances. Experts weigh in on how to make an informed decision.
Do multivitamins ensure your body gets everything it needs? It's a complicated question without a one-size-fits-all answer.
While thereâ€™s no doubt taking multivitamins may benefit some people, experts suggest assessing your nutritional needs before popping a daily multivitamin.
â€œA large amount of vitamins can cause nausea, vomiting, dehydration, confusion, and organ damage, such as [to the] liver or kidney,â€ says medical oncologist Liudmila Schafer. â€œAdditionally, multivâ€¦

entry.title: 8 hotels that offer a taste of 'quiet luxury'
entry.summary:
Mollie, a hotel in Aspen, uses earthy tones, ceramics, hand-dyed fabrics, and natural textures in its 68 rooms and suites. This cultural and design trend is all about understated elegance. You can indulge on the road, too, in these eight hotels that offer everything from perfectly weighted linens to zoned lighting and heated floors.
In recent years, quiet luxuryâ€”a trend of pared-back elegance driven by cultural phenomenon and social media influencersâ€”took over fashion. The same ethos has been guiding travelers to certain hotels.
â€œQuiet luxuryÂ is about spaces that feel effortlessly refined, where everything has been carefully considered but nothing screams for attention,â€ says Pamela Schein Murphy, founder of Wandrist Travel. She notes that details like the texture and weight oâ€¦

entry.title: Here's why Friday the 13th scares us
entry.summary:
Scholars believe the superstition around Friday the 13th may have roots in religious beliefsâ€”but most research has shown that the day isn't any more unlucky than other days on the calendar.

Find out how the date got its unlucky reputation and how even nonbelievers may be influenced by our collective triskaidekaphobia. The creepiest day on the calendar has returned: Friday the 13th. In 2023, there were two ill-fated Fridays, one in January and another in October. In 2024, we saw two again, in September and December. This year, we're back to one, on June 13. But it seems that no matter how many of these frightening Fridays we survive unharmed, the dreaded day continues to inspire unease and fears of misfortune. Thereâ€™s no logical reason to fear the occasional coâ€¦

entry.title: A new childrenâ€™s book celebrates our amazing origins in Africa
entry.summary:
Youâ€™ve probably heard that we can all trace our roots back to Africa. Itâ€™s a fact that most people learn about briefly in a history class or find out through 23andMe. Still, this shared origin story often feels like a blip in our consciousness compared to other time periods. Itâ€™s a commonality weâ€™re willing to acknowledge but not always explore.Â Â
Picture-book author and film illustrator Nikkolas Smith fills in this curiosity gap with his latest book, The History of We, which he both wrote and illustrated. The self-described â€œartivistâ€ has dedicated much of his career to rendering crucial moments and people in Black history through expressive paintings, from portraits of George Floyd and Breonna Taylor to a comic-book treatment of the Obamas. One of his most well-known projects is Theâ€¦

entry.title: 6 of the best summer festivals to travel to, according to an expert
entry.summary:
One of the most famous Midsummer celebrations is found in the central Swedish town of Leksand. Festivals, when cultures reveals themselves most vividly, are some of the best times to visit a new destination â€” here are the six best summer festivals to travel to this summer.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
Thereâ€™s no better time to visit a new place than during a festival. These heightened moments, special points in the calendar, are when a culture reveals itself most vividly: town squares are festooned with flowers and draped in finery, people conceal themselves beneath extravagant costumes and wild-eyed masks, and the air is filled with the sound of music and the delicious smells of festival food.
But beyond just being outwardly captivatâ€¦

entry.title: The secret to early animal sketches? Butterfly dust
entry.summary: Jan van Kessel the Elder. Noahâ€™s Family Assembling Animals Before the Ark, c. 1660 oil on panel. A first-ever collaboration between the National Gallery of Art and the Smithsonian examines the birth of natural history. The National Gallery of Art and the Smithsonianâ€™s Natural History Museum have been next-door neighbors in Washington, DC for nearly 90 yearsâ€”but until now, theyâ€™ve never shared so much as a cup of coffee across the fence. That all changes this summer, as the two institutions collaborate to create a cross-pollinated art and natural science exhibition featuring selections from the art galleryâ€™s centuries-old paintings of birds, bugs, and exotic critters â€¦ along with actual examples of those creatures drawn from the Smithsonianâ€™s enormous collection of animâ€¦

entry.title: Vera Rubin was the GOAT of dark matter
entry.summary:
Astronomer Vera Rubin spent much of her career at the Carnegie Institutionâ€™s Department of Terrestrial Magnetism in Washington, D.C. She's best known for convincing the world that dark matter exists. How the pioneering scientist, and namesake of an enormous new telescope, forced astronomers to rethink the universe.
Vera Rubin had just finished her ice cream when she saw something that would change astronomy forever. It was long past midnight one early morning in the 1960s, and Rubin and her colleague Kent Ford were at Kitt Peak National Observatory in the middle of the Arizona desert. That night they were tracking how hot gas from young stars circled Andromeda, the Milky Wayâ€™s galactic neighbor. Rubin and Ford would trade off recording the gasesâ€™ chemical fingerprints or processinâ€¦

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: About Pew Research Centerâ€™s Spring 2025 Global Attitudes Survey Results for the survey are based on a mix of telephone, face-to-face and online interviews conducted under the direction of Gallup, Langer Research Associates and Social Research Centre. The results are based on national samples, unless otherwise noted. Read more about our international survey methodology and [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Richard Wike, Director, Global Attitudes ResearchJacob Poushter, Associate Director, Global Attitudes ResearchLaura Silver, Associate Director, Global Attitudes ResearchJanell Fetterolf, Senior Researcher Dorene Asare-Marfo, Senior Panel ManagerPeter Bell, Associate Director, Design and ProductionJanakee Chavda, Associate Digital ProducerLaura Clancy, Research AnalystJonathan [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix C: Detailed charts, Trumpâ€™s characteristics
entry.summary: The post Appendix C: Detailed charts, Trumpâ€™s characteristics appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix B: Classifying European political parties
entry.summary: Classifying parties as populist Although experts generally agree that populist political leaders or parties display high levels of anti-elitism, definitions of populism vary. We use three measures to classify populist parties: anti-elite ratings from the 2019 Chapel Hill Expert Survey (CHES), Norrisâ€™ Global Party Survey and The PopuList. We define a party as populist when [â€¦] The post Appendix B: Classifying European political parties appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix A: Global Attitudes Survey fieldwork timeline
entry.summary: There were many events, meetings and announcements that occurred shortly before and during our fieldwork period that may have impacted how people in other countries perceive the U.S. and its president. We highlight a few prominent events here that were relevant across multiple countries and directly relate to the questions included in our survey. The post Appendix A: Global Attitudes Survey fieldwork timeline appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 5. Comparing confidence in Trump, Macron, Putin and Xi
entry.summary: Macron receives the highest ratings across the 24 countries surveyed, followed by Trump, but views of these two leaders diverge sharply in several nations. The post 5. Comparing confidence in Trump, Macron, Putin and Xi appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. Views of Trumpâ€™s characteristics
entry.summary: Majorities in many countries surveyed describe Trump as arrogant, dangerous and a strong leader. Relatively few see him as well-qualified to be president, diplomatic or honest. The post 4. Views of Trumpâ€™s characteristics appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Confidence in Trump to handle global issues
entry.summary: On balance, most people across 24 nations are not confident in Trump to handle immigration, conflict in Ukraine and Israel, China relations, the global economy, and climate change. The post 3. Confidence in Trump to handle global issues appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Confidence in Trump
entry.summary: Across 24 nations, a median of 34% have confidence in Trump, while 62% do not. Trump receives lower ratings than Biden did in many countries surveyed. The post 2. Confidence in Trump appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Views of the United States
entry.summary: Across 24 nations, a 49% median view the U.S. favorably, while an identical share do not. People are also roughly split on whether U.S. democracy works well. The post 1. Views of the United States appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Gang violence displaces a record 1.3 million Haitians
entry.summary: Nearly 1.3 million people have been forced to flee gang violence in Haiti and seek refuge elsewhere within the Caribbean country, the International Organization for Migration (IOM) said Wednesday.

entry.title: Rising hunger in Gaza highlights urgent need for â€˜unfetteredâ€™ aid supplies
entry.summary: People in the Gaza Strip are getting hungrier because of the â€œvery limitedâ€ volume of food being allowed in, UN aid agencies reiterated on Wednesday.

entry.title: Ukraine: Ongoing Russian strikes continue alarming civilian casualty trend
entry.summary: Civilian deaths and injuries in the first five months of 2025 were nearly 50 per cent higher than the same period last year, UN rights experts tasked with monitoring abuses in war-torn Ukraine said on Wednesday in their latestÂ report.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Climate emergency is a health crisis â€˜that is already killing us,â€™ says WHO
entry.summary: With 2024 confirmed as the hottest year on record, the World Health Organization (WHO) has issued a stark warning: the climate crisis is also a health crisis â€“ and itâ€™s already claiming lives.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜Plenty of fish in the seaâ€™? Not anymore, say UN experts in Nice
entry.summary: At the Third UN Ocean Conference in Nice, the â€œcatch of the dayâ€ wasnâ€™t a seabass or a red mullet â€“ it was a figure: 35 per cent. Thatâ€™s the share of global fish stocks now being harvested unsustainably, according to a new UN report released Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: The world pledged to end child labour by 2025: So why are 138 million kids still working?
entry.summary: 12-year-old Tenasoa crawls to work every day at a mine in eastern Madagascar where she collects two kilos of the shiny mineral mica each day. She cannot walk because of a physical disability.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: At least eight die in Red Sea tragedy as smugglers force migrants overboard
entry.summary: Survivors of a people-smuggling operation gone wrong in the Red Sea have recounted how they were forced off their boat far from the coast of Djibouti and left to swim for their lives.

entry.title: Do dogs need people to survive? The truth might hurt.
entry.summary:
A group of dogs greets their human family on a farm. A miniature dachshund survived in the wild for 529 days. Could your dog? Experts say it depends on these traits.
In late April, a miniature dachshund named Valerie was found healthy and alert on Kangaroo Island, just off the coast of Adelaide, Australiaâ€”after she had been missing for 529 days.Â Â
Surprisingly, Valerie, who had become separated from her family during a vacation to the island in November 2023, had even gained about four pounds in the wild.
â€œShe went out as a skinny little sausage dog and came back as a rippling mass of muscle,â€ saysÂ Jared Karran, a director at the nonprofitÂ Kangala Wildlife Rescue, who releasedÂ footageÂ of Valerieâ€™s rescue. â€œJust the healthiest dog you'd ever want to seeâ€”perfect teeth, perâ€¦

entry.title: Love Sicily but not the crowds? Visit this island instead
entry.summary:
Pollara, located on the northwest side of Salina, was created by a partially collapsed volcanic crater. Just a boat ride from Sicily, the island of Salina offers an authentic, laid-back Italian getaway with volcanic cliffs, lush landscapes, and extraordinary views.
Hop on a hydrofoil from Milazzo, Sicily, and in less than two hours youâ€™ll find yourself on the beautiful island of Salina. Stromboli's volcano stands tall on the distant horizon, and unlike Sicily, there are not many crowds of people. Locals whizz by on mopeds while only a few tourists relax at a sea cove on the side of the road.
Salina is the second-largest island in the Aeolian archipelago (Lipari is the largest), yet it is home to only around 2,500 residents, making the island the perfect immersion into relaxed â€¦

entry.title: 200 years ago, tourists flocked to Parisâ€”to see corpses
entry.summary:
This mid-1800s illustration shows how the Paris Morgue put unidentified bodies on public displayâ€”drawing crowds of curious onlookers behind the glass. Before true crime and reality TV, there was the Paris Morgueâ€”where crowds queued to see the dead. It was the first of its kind, and for decades, the cityâ€™s strangest attraction.
In 1870s Paris, expensive plate glass panes meant one of two things: high-end shopping or public spectacle. At la Morgue de Paris, it meant both.
Inside, the cityâ€™s unclaimed dead lay on tilted marble slabs beneath a trickle of water meant to stave off decay. While some still wore the clothes they were found in, most were naked, with only leather loincloths placed over their genitals. Other garmentsâ€”coats, boots, even umbrellasâ€”were hung above or beside â€¦

entry.title: From Stonehenge to Sedona, why are we drawn to mystical places?
entry.summary:
Places like Stonehenge, Machu Picchu, and the Borobudur Temple can stir up deep emotional responses in the human brain, scientists and researchers say. Sacred sites have long lured travelers seeking a connection to something bigger. In a world grappling with digital overload, these pilgrimages are on the rise.
As the sun rises at Chaco Canyon, shadows stretch across ancient sandstone with such precise astronomical alignment that itâ€™s easy to believe it was designed for a cosmic purpose. At Machu Picchu, the intricate stonework and mountaintop design reveal feats of engineering that leave visitors in quiet reverence. Sedonaâ€™s red rocks hum with rumored energy vortexes. On the Salisbury Plain, Stonehenge casts shadows both on the landscape and on its original purpose.Â
Across thâ€¦

entry.title: She's inspiring a new future for Africaâ€™s nomadic herders
entry.summary:
Long before European powers carved up West Africa and independent African states inherited their contemporary borders, a great nomadic tradition beganâ€”one that continues and evolves today. Around November, as the rainy season ends and the southern fringes of the Sahara desert begin to dry and brown again, hundreds of thousands of Fulani herders gather to drive millions of cattle, goats, and sheep toward cooler subtropical savannas.
This annual movement has made the Fulani one of the largest nomadic groups on Earth, but it has also helped exclude them from politics: Despite their large numbers, the transient herders are less likely to be counted by states. An added obstacle to representation is the fact that many of the regionâ€™s governments are more invested in farming than herding. Thâ€¦

entry.title: Scientists are solving the mystery of how axolotls regrow limbs
entry.summary:
When a sharp shrub severs a salamander tail or it loses an arm in a predator fight, the animal sits back and waits. Within weeks, the missing body part regrows good as new.Â
For years scientists have wondered how these amphibians work this magic, and whether humans might one day follow suit. A study published June 10th in Nature Communications takes a giant step in understanding the phenomenon, detailing the biology by which axolotls regrow the exact missing limb in its proper place.
Retinoic acid, a substance also abundant in the human bodyâ€”as well as in many skin creamsâ€”has long been known to be a major player. Now itâ€™s clear that a particular enzyme (which humans have too) finely tunes levels of the retinoid at the animalâ€™s wound site to ensure the correct part appears. At theâ€¦

entry.title: Love whisky? Here's where to try it in Scotland
entry.summary:
The red-brick, riverside buildings that make up Deanston Distillery were in fact an 18th-century cotton mill, before they were converted to whisky-making in 1966. Whether youâ€™re a single-malt connoisseur or whisky newbie, a distillery pilgrimage should be part of every Scottish trip.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
Pagoda chimneys rising above pine-forested glens, the babble of a highland spring, the distinctive aroma of toasted malt â€” distilleries are far more than functional factories. Often set in spectacular settings, theyâ€™re crucibles of living, breathing Scottish heritage. And many invite visitors inside to view bubbling mash tuns, gleaming copper stills and warehouses filled with oak barrels, revealing the almost alchemical process thaâ€¦

entry.title: We've never seen this rare squid alive in the wildâ€”until now
entry.summary: In the frigid waters near Antarctica, the elusive squid Gonatus antarcticus was recently spotted by a remotely operated vehicle. It's the first time this squid has been seen alive. In the deep seas found at the Earthâ€™s poles, explorers are still finding elusive and mysterious sea creatures. On an expedition in the Southern Ocean, researchers captured stunning video of the Antarctic gonate squid for the first time. Reporting in this article is presented by the National Geographic Society in partnership with Rolex under the National Geographic and Rolex Perpetual Planet Ocean Expeditions. It was late on Christmas Eve and the frigid waters of the Southern Ocean's Weddell Sea weren't cooperating.Â Â  The scientists and crew onboard the Schmidt Ocean Instituteâ€™s ship R.â€¦

entry.title: Can Africaâ€™s great nomadic people save their way of life?
entry.summary:
Near the southern edgeÂ of the Sahara desert, millions of people in some 20 West and Central African countries share a way of life. Year after year, they take part in the ancient practice of nomadic pastoralism, herding livestock across increasingly hot, arid lands of the Sahel region in search of fresh grasslandsÂ and accessible water as the seasons change. From the western coast of Senegal to the eastern shorelines of Sudan, herders follow different migratory routes that can cover hundreds of miles. Â
Most of these pastoralists share another important distinction: They are Fulani, an Indigenous people who have a broad cultural identity shaped by such traditional journeys. These groups are vast and varied, and many are traveling in new directions. https://interactives.natgeofe.comâ€¦

entry.title: Global action needed as progress stalls on disability-inclusive development goals
entry.summary: Nearly all the Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) indicators for persons with disabilities are off track the UN deputy chief said on Tuesday, as people from around the world gathered for the largest annual meeting on disability-related issues.

entry.summary: The top UN official in Iraq reiterated his confidence in the resilience of the countryâ€™s people, and the determination of their leaders, in a briefing to the Security Council on Tuesday.

entry.title: The battle to quiet the sea: Can the shipping industry turn down the volume?
entry.summary: The ocean has never been silent â€“ waves crashing, seabirds calling, whales singing across vast distances. But in recent decades, a new kind of noise has taken hold: the relentless hum of ships. For many marine species, this growing wall of sound is more than a nuisance â€“ itâ€™s a threat to their survival.

entry.summary: The Israeli militaryâ€™s destruction of Gazaâ€™s education and cultural infrastructure amount to war crimes and the crime against humanity of extermination, a UN investigative body said on Tuesday, as humanitarian agencies warned of continued mass suffering across the Strip.

entry.title: Greed is driving oceans toward collapse
entry.summary: The ocean is under siege â€“ and greed is to blame. UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres on Tuesday urged world leaders and grassroots groups alike to confront the powerful interests driving marine destruction, from illegal fishing and plastic pollution to the accelerating impacts of climate change.

entry.title: Sudan emergency: We need more help to prevent famine, says WFP
entry.summary: The very real risk of famine continues to stalk Sudanâ€™s communities impacted by war, the UN World Food Programme (WFP) said on Tuesday, in an appeal for more funding to support immediate needs and boost longer-term recovery across the country.

entry.title: Social and economic barriers, not choice, driving global fertility crisis: UNFPA
entry.summary: The global fertility slump isnâ€™t down to young people turning their backs on parenthood â€“ itâ€™s due to social and economic pressures stopping them from having the children they want, says a new UN report.

entry.title: Europeâ€™s city tours are better than everâ€”hereâ€™s where to go
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
There was a time when a perfunctory potter round the key sites with a dusty guide serviced by an even dustier script was the summit of our city-tour ambitions. Now, driven by a new breed of innovative and passionate advocates eager to exalt their home towns, the choice is boundless. Whether youâ€™re looking to scratch the surface of a destination or really get under its skin, you wonâ€™t struggle to find a tour as unique, compelling and fun as the guides who lead them. Here, we celebrate a selection of the latter â€” from a retired policeman on a very different beat in London to a Barcelona â€˜sightjoggerâ€™ and a kayaker offering an unusual take on the City of Bridges.
Visitors to Venice have been getting out on the waterâ€¦

entry.title: Jellyfish are finally giving up their secrets
entry.summary:
A pair of sea butterflies (Corolla spectabilis) drift just beneath the surface. Though they might not look like it, these are actually snails that have evolved wings to live in the water column. Scientists are unraveling the mysteries of the oceanâ€™s squishiest creaturesâ€”including one jelly that might be the oldest animal species on Earth.
Gelatinous zooplankton, colloquially known as jellies, are an evolutionary hodge-podge of squishy, translucent creatures composed mostly of water. While this group does include â€œtrue jellyfishâ€ with their iconic rounded bell and stinging tentacles, it is also host to a smattering of creatures such as worms, primitive chordates, and snails with wings.
â€œIf being 95 percent water is what unites the group, that is where it ends,â€ says Grace Câ€¦

entry.title: A giant mass of seaweed threatens beach season in the U.S.
entry.summary:
The Great Atlantic Sargassum Beltâ€”a goopy mass of leafy, floating seaweed stretching across 5,000 milesâ€”is slated to be a nuisance of record breaking proportions this year. In May, scientists at the University of South Florida observed over 37 million metric tons of sargassum in the Caribbean Sea, Atlantic Ocean, and Gulf of Mexico.
Later this month, the seaweed will continue washing ashore on Caribbean and U.S. beaches.
In the past decade it's increasingly become a problem for beachgoers and seaside businessesâ€”and a rotting, smelly one at thatâ€”but sargassum is a natural part of the ocean food chain.
â€œIn the vast expanse of the ocean, it can be an oasis,â€ says Brian Barnes, a marine scientist at the University of South Florida. The patches of seaweed can be a home and sourceâ€¦

entry.title: 10 stunning UNESCO sites that were immortalized on screen
entry.summary: A local Jordanian Bedouin leads his camels through the desert to Wadi Rum, a UNESCO World Heritage Site featured in movies such as Dune, Lawrence of Arabia, The Martian, and Star Wars films. From the "Tomb Raider Temple" to Dune's alien landscapes, these iconic destinations captured the attention of early set-jetters. In 1989, the appearance of Petraâ€™s ancient tomb known as the Treasury [Al-Khazneh] in Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade electrified moviegoers. Following the filmâ€™s release, annual attendance at Jordanâ€™s formerly obscure UNESCO World Heritage Site skyrocketedâ€”reaching nearly a million visitors by 2010. Today, the link between the haunting, rock-faced tombs and the Hollywood blockbuster continues to capture the attention of setâ€¦

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: This section describes the methods used to estimate religious composition at the country level, regionally and globally; our procedures for measuring religious groupsâ€™ demographic characteristics and their religious â€œswitchingâ€ rates; as well as methodological challenges that we considered in some countries. The final section lists the 201 countries and territories that make up each of [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report was produced by Pew Research Center as part of the Pew-Templeton Global Religious Futures project, which analyzes religious change and its impact on societies around the world. Funding for the Global Religious Futures project comes from The Pew Charitable Trusts and the John Templeton Foundation (grant 62287). Find related reports online atÂ https://www.pewresearch.org/globalreligiousfutures. This [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 14. Religion in sub-Saharan Africa
entry.summary: Most people in sub-Saharan Africa are Christian. Christians and Muslims grew rapidly in number in the region from 2010 to 2020. The post 14. Religion in sub-Saharan Africa appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 13. Religion in North America
entry.summary: A majority of North Americans are Christian. But Christian populations declined in the U.S. and Canada, while the unaffiliated grew, from 2010 to 2020. The post 13. Religion in North America appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 12. Religion in the Middle East and North Africa
entry.summary: Every religious group grew in count in the Middle East and North Africa â€“ a Muslim-majority region â€“ between 2010 and 2020. The post 12. Religion in the Middle East and North Africa appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 11. Religion in Latin America and the Caribbean
entry.summary: Most people in the Latin America-Caribbean region are Christian. The region's unaffiliated population grew rapidly since 2010. The post 11. Religion in Latin America and the Caribbean appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 10. Religion in Europe
entry.summary: Christians are still a majority in Europe but disaffiliation thinned the Christian population from 2010 to 2020. The post 10. Religion in Europe appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 9. Religion in Asia and the Pacific
entry.summary: Hindus, Muslims and the unaffiliated each make up about a quarter or more of the Asia-Pacific population. These groups all grew there from 2010-2020. The post 9. Religion in Asia and the Pacific appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 8. Jewish population change
entry.summary: Jewish people make up 0.2% of the world population. Jews rose in number by 6% from 2010 to 2020, mostly due to growth in Israel. The post 8. Jewish population change appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 7. â€˜Other religionsâ€™ population change
entry.summary: Bahaâ€™is, Jains, Sikhs, Daoists and other groups that Pew Research Center classified as "other religions" combined â€“ grew globally by 12% from 2010 to 2020. The post 7. â€˜Other religionsâ€™ population change appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: How to plan an epic road trip through Baja California
entry.summary:
Many travelers complete this route in two weeks, but the more time you have, the better. This is the perfect route to discover the magic of Mexicoâ€™s Baja peninsula, from its pristine beaches to charming historic towns and unspoiled landscapes.
Mexico was made for road trips. Its landscapes are diverse, breathtaking, and adventure-packed, as well as filled with cultural experiences and mouthwatering cuisine. My husband and I have driven over 10,000 miles across Mexico in our RV, and while weâ€™ve loved our year-and-a-half trip, one route stood out above the rest: the Baja California peninsula.
Jutting off from California and wedged between the Pacific Ocean and the Gulf of California, the Baja California peninsula is the ultimate road trip for adventure seekers. The journey down â€¦

entry.title: Where to drink in Jerez, the birthplace of Spanish sherry
entry.summary:
El Pasaje is the townâ€™s oldest tabanco, or sherry bar. In the midst of a revival, Spainâ€™s famed fortified wine is best sampled at the source â€” in the whitewashed Andalucian town of Jerez de la Frontera, where locals bond in bodegas and bars.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
A pretty place with a jumble of Moorish-style courtyards, gothic churches and grand baroque buildings, the small Andalucian city of Jerez is largely untouched by gentrification and tourism â€” despite being only an hour from Seville. Yet it has a long-held reputation as the countryâ€™s sherry capital: â€˜jerezâ€™ means â€˜sherryâ€™ in Spanish and the fortified wine has been made here for over 3,000 years.
Once considered old fashioned, sherry has stepped back into the spotlight iâ€¦

entry.title: 5 vineyard restaurants to visit in England
entry.summary:
Hambledon Vineyard's award-winning sparkling wines include the classic cuvee and, new for 2025, its first blanc de blancs. Englandâ€™s top wineries are increasingly pairing their vintages with smart dishes that draw on the best local produce.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
In the UKâ€™s dynamic wine scene, seasonally led vineyard restaurants are becoming as much of a draw as the wine itself, ideal for languid summer afternoons. Here are five of the best to whet your appetite â€” from Michelin-starred venues getting creative with locally foraged ingredients to an East Sussex hotspot where wood-wired pizzas are paired with the perfect natural wine.
Operating since 1952, Hambledon is the UKâ€™s oldest commercial winery. Its award-winning sparklâ€¦

entry.title: What dinosaur has 500 teeth? This ancient jaw was one-of-a-kind
entry.summary:
What dinosaur has 500 teeth and replaced each and every one of them every 14 days? With 15 times more teeth than the human set of 32,Â Nigersaurus taqueti hacked through low-lying vegetation with choppers like a lawn mower, paleontologist and National Geographic Explorer Paul Sereno told National GeographicÂ just years after he and colleagues first described and named the dinosaur.Â
About as heavy as an adultÂ African forest elephant, this dinosaur would have weighed about two tons and stretched about 30 feet long from nose to the tip of its tail. The herbivore wandered lowlands of western Africa about 105 million years ago in whatâ€™s now the Republic of Niger.
NigersaurusÂ was one of the most effective plant-eating creatures to have ever evolved. Hereâ€™s what you need to know aboutÂ Niâ€¦

entry.title: These 6 European cities are synonymous with music
entry.summary:
The House of Strauss is the worldâ€™s only remaining concert hall where all four Strausses performed. Whether an old folk ballad or a futuristic techno hit, music is the lifeblood of Europeâ€™s great cities and one of the most powerful ways to connect with its storied past and electric present.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
While many cities can lay claim to being hubs of musical creativity, only a few become truly synonymous with a certain sound. After all, Vienna will always waltz to the tune of Strauss and few can imagine Seville without the passion of flamenco. In some cases, a city is its music. And, like that of a gifted composer, the European repertoire is vast. Whether for pop or classical, folk or techno, travellers will find no shortâ€¦

entry.title: Gaza: Search for food puts lives on the line
entry.summary: The worsening humanitarian crisis in the Gaza Strip has reached â€œunprecedented levels of despair,â€ the UN said on Monday, amid more reports of people being killed and injured near newly-established distribution sites.

entry.title: No green without blue: Young ocean explorers set sail for a sustainable future
entry.summary: With science at the forefront of the opening day of the Third UN Ocean Conference (UNOC3), UN News boarded a 111-year-old Norwegian tall ship on the French Riviera to meet 50 science students, along with a host of lecturers and citizen scientists fresh from a 46-day expedition. Fueled by satellite data from the European Space Agency (ESA), their invaluable observations echo the urgent call to understand and protect the worldâ€™s oceans.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Lack of cooperation from Iran hampers nuclear checks, says atomic energy watchdog
entry.summary: The head of the UN-backed nuclear watchdog has raised fresh concerns over Iranâ€™s failure to fully cooperate with inspections, warning that this is preventing independent verification of its nuclear activities.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Central Africa at a crossroads amid rising tensions and instability
entry.summary: Despite its wealth of natural resources and potential, Central Africa continues to face serious challenges, from political instability to growing humanitarian needs.

entry.title: How We Revealed Mega-Polluters Taking Advantage of Green Loans
entry.summary: An exposÃ© supported by the Pulitzer Center's Rainforest Investigations Networks found loans earmarked for green projects were routinely used by fossil fuel and mining companies.

entry.title: Drifting architects: Plankton, climate, and the race to understand our changing ocean
entry.summary: They drift unseen, but everything depends on them. Plankton â€“ the oceanâ€™s lifeblood â€“Â regulate the climate, feed the seas, and shape life on Earth. On the French Riviera, scientists are racing to unlock their secrets before the hush of their decline echoes across the planet.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: Women and girls struggle to manage their periods amid crisis
entry.summary: Whether itâ€™s their first time or a routine part of their life, menstruation has become a nightmare for women and girls in Gaza. The conditions they are forced to endure - displacement, overcrowded shelters, and lack of basic hygiene - have turned a natural biological process into a monthly ordeal.

entry.title: Love Moroccan architecture? Try this city instead of Marrakech
entry.summary:
You can organise a guided tour of the Hassan II Mosque with CasamÃ©moire, a non-profit thatâ€™s been working to preserve the cityâ€™s 20th-century architecture since 1995. Located on the Atlantic coast of Morocco, the nationâ€™s most populous city is a layer cake of soaring mosques, art deco cinemas and technicolour murals.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Casablanca is well versed in transformation. Anfa, the Amazigh settlement that once stood here, was obliterated by the Portuguese in 1468. When they returned to rebuild the town half a century later, they renamed it â€˜Casa Brancaâ€™ (White House). An earthquake then levelled the region in 1755, prompting Moroccan ruler Sultan Mohammed ben Abdallah to build the whitewashed Medina. Earning itself the loâ€¦

entry.title: Stigmatised for being deaf: ZÃ©nabou's Story
entry.summary: In the Central African Republic, disability carriesÂ a deep-rooted stigma, and persons with disabilities often find themselves excluded from almost every avenue of life. ZÃ©nabou, who is deaf and non-speaking, has suffered from prejudice, but a UN-backed educational programme offers a glimmer of hope.

entry.title: Chengdu's ancient teahouses are going viralâ€”here's why
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Itâ€™s barely 9am when I slide into a bamboo armchair at Heming Tea House in Chengduâ€™s sprawling Peopleâ€™s Park. This century-old stalwart is one of the oldest teahouses in the megacity that I called home until I was nine. While I was growing up here, in one of Chinaâ€™s oldest tea-growing areas, many weekends were spent in an open-air teahouse like this one.
While adults played games of mahjong and the kids ran riot, roving hawkers carrying heavy baskets balanced on bamboo shoulder poles would come round selling snacks. The most famous of these is dan dan mian (shoulder pole noodles), where a nest of cold noodles is placed on a hot and tongue-numbing mala chilli oil base, topped with spring onion and minced meat, thenâ€¦

entry.title: 9 Rome restaurants locals swear by
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
In Rome, where every other restaurant promises a â€˜trueâ€™ carbonara or â€˜classicâ€™ pizza, the pursuit of authenticity can feel elusive. Travellers often stay within the confines of the historical centre and rely on the greatest hits served in well-worn trattorias offering English-language menus. But do as the locals do and seek out culinary quality in Romeâ€™s quieter corners and youâ€™ll really get a flavour of the city. From contemporary trattorias to wine kiosks, here are nine of the best places to eat in Rome â€” trusted spots that locals return to time after time. Duck ragÃ¹ clings to strands of chitarra pasta in this deeply flavourful primo at Santo Palato. Santo Palatoâ€™s tiramisu comes unapologetically tall, with geâ€¦

entry.title: 10 places where you can ditch your car this summer
entry.summary:
Pedestrians stroll through the old town in Há»™i An, Vietnam. A river trading port from the 15th through 19th centuries, itâ€™s one of many destinations around the globe that ban or severely limit cars. You can walk, hike, and bikeâ€”but not driveâ€”through these destinations that prohibit automobiles.
More thanÂ 45 million U.S. travelersÂ took road trips for Memorial Day 2025â€”an increase of approximately one million from the previous year, breaking the 2005 record of 44 million people driving to their desired destination for the holiday weekend.
Choosing a car-free destination is a way both to save at the pump and help save the planet. Places that prohibit, or at least greatly restrict, motorized vehicles range from the well-known (Venice, Italy, the worldâ€™s largest pedestrian zone), tâ€¦

entry.title: The butterfly effect is a real phenomenonâ€”but not how you think
entry.summary:
In 1961, MIT meteorologist Edward Lorenz was inputting numbers into a weather prediction program. His model was based on a dozen variables, the value of one being .506127. When he ran the model again, he rounded that number to .506, then left the room to grab a coffee. When he came back, he discovered this tiny change had resulted in a dramatically different weather prediction.
When presenting his resultant groundbreaking model of chaos and the potential of extreme chaotic unpredictability at the 1972 meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS), Lorenz posed the question: â€œDoes the flap of a butterflyâ€™s wings in Brazil set off a tornado in Texas?â€Â
Richard A. Anthes, former president of the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, â€¦

entry.title: Take a solo trip to the honeymoon capital of the world
entry.summary:
After two overnight flights and a brief stop in Istanbul, I found myself island-hopping alone through the Maldives on a tiny seaplane surrounded by couples. I was the last stop: Velaa Private Islandâ€”a palm-studded speck of sand in the middle of the impossibly blue Indian Ocean. The Maldives is often associated with honeymoons and vacations for couples, but it is a destination for everyone. Some of the villas are accessible only by boat. There are certain destinations that seem made for couples. Paris is one that lives large in our imaginations, conjuring images of strolling hand in hand along the Seine. The Maldives is another, with white sand beaches, luxury resorts, and overwater bungalows that are almost synonymous with the word â€œhoneymoon."
I always thought the Mâ€¦

entry.title: Can hypnosis really treat hot flashes?
entry.summary:
The use of hypnosis for medical and psychological purposes dates back centuries. In the 18th century, Austrian physician Franz Anton Mesmer believed â€œmesmerismâ€ to be caused by an invisible fluid between the subject and the therapist. The practice was used to alter the perception of pain in surgical patients, and help people with psychological issues.
Today hypnosis is understood to be a subjective state in which perception or memory can be evoked by suggestion. While our understanding of hypnotism has evolved, the practice is still a useful tool for both medicine and psychology. Modern day hypnotism has been used in battling addiction, provide relief from chronic pain, and most recently reducing the occurrence of hot flashes.Â
Most women begin the menopausal transition, when theâ€¦

entry.title: 7 places around the world that honor LGBTQ+ history
entry.summary:
Qtopia Sydneyâ€”once the Darlinghurst Police Stationâ€”is a museum and cultural center for queer history and culture. It features 18 exhibitions, spanning five major themes: HIV/AIDS, human rights, sexuality and identity, media representation, and First Nations stories. From Florida to Germany, these institutions are dedicated to preserving and celebrating queer history, art, and culture year-round.
Curious travelers seeking to understand different culturesâ€”near and abroadâ€”can cure their curiosity by visiting historic landmarks and museums. The same can be done when expanding one's knowledge about the LGBTQ+ community and its historyâ€”and not just during Pride month in June. These places are open to the public year-round and collect, preserve, and share untold LGBTQ+ stories and contribâ€¦

entry.title: Humans can't survive without a healthy Ocean: UN envoy
entry.summary: The Ocean is in deep crisis. Factors such as acidification, declining fish stocks, rising temperatures and widespread pollution are contributing to a catastrophic decline in biodiversity: over half of marine species are at risk of extinction this century.

entry.title: â€˜Make-or-Break Momentâ€™: Wahyu Dhyatmika on the Growing Threats Confronting Independent Journalism in Indonesia
entry.summary: For veteran journalist Wahyu Dhyatmika, Indonesia's intensely challenging press climate is a wake-up call for the media to retool its business model and refocus on serving the public.

entry.title: Koala moms make their kids eat poo. Itâ€™s for their own good.
entry.summary:
When itâ€™s time to feed the kids, koala moms do their doody. Then the little ones snack on it.
Before you poo-poo the idea, a koala mom feedingÂ a form ofÂ excrement to their young is a life-saving precaution called papping.Â
â€œPap is aÂ different type of fecesÂ than their normal feces,â€ saysÂ Sally Bornbusch, a research associate at the Smithsonianâ€™s National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute. Adult koalas eat only eucalyptus leaves, which are toxic to most animalsâ€”and baby koalas, aka joeys, canâ€™t digest them yet.Â
When theyâ€™re born, koalas are less than an inch long, and they look more like a gummy bear than a koala bear. They make their way from the birth canal to momâ€™s pouch, where they will stay and nurse for about seven months.Â
The babies donâ€™t have the guts, so tâ€¦

entry.title: The surprisingly relatable reason why some birds get cranky
entry.summary:
Some bird species, like the European robin seen here, act more aggressively when living in city environments. A new study shows that one group of GalÃ¡pagos yellow warblers responds to intruders more aggressively than others. It adds compelling new evidence to a theory about angry birds.
Trafficked roads, loud noises,Â suffocating smog. For some people, living in the city can be stressful and unnerving. But a growing body of research shows some city birds can be more aggressive than their rural counterparts, suggesting they too feel the pressures of city life.
In a study published in April in the journal Animal Behavior, researchers showed that GalÃ¡pagos yellow warblers that live near trafficked roads in the Ecuadorian archipelago respond to intruders more aggressively than thoâ€¦

entry.title: A new blood test can tell if cancer has returned
entry.summary:
New blood tests can detect cancer recurrence earlier than traditional scans, potentially giving doctors and patients crucial information to make decisions about treatment. But more studies are needed to determine whether these detections change survival rates.  But whether patients should be getting the testsâ€”as some already areâ€”is not yet clear.
When Jennifer Feenstra was diagnosed with advanced, aggressive lung cancer five years ago, she didnâ€™t waste time fretting about how she, a non-smoking fitness buff, could have gotten the disease. Instead, the 59-year-old retired graphic designer from Stamford, Connecticut, was determined to throw everything at it.
After surgeons at the Yale Cancer Center removed part of her right lung, she endured four rounds of gruelinâ€¦

entry.title: See France's Basque coast through the eyes of a photographer
entry.summary:
The harbour at St-Jean-de-Luz offers a view to Ciboure, south of Biarritz, where the town and its neighbours retain a nostalgic charm. The pearl of Franceâ€™s Basque coast, Biarritz has long been a playground for European high society. Today, the town and its neighbours retain a nostalgic charm, with visitors drawn to the region for fine dining, belle epoque architecture and surf breaks.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). The coupleâ€™s summertime sojourns made the belle Ã©poque-era seaside town popular with European royalty. But crowns and tiaras could not outshine the landâ€™s unique Basque heritage, evident in its language, artistic expression and food culture. Basque cuisine remains popular to this day, from the traditional bakeries thatâ€¦

entry.title: â€˜Unstableâ€™ asteroids lurk around Venusâ€”is Earth at risk?
entry.summary:
Venus has groupiesâ€”a family of asteroids that share its orbit, either trailing it or leading it as the planet revolves around the sun. Researchers have known that such stealthy space rocks might exist for years, but now, a pair of papers (one published in a journal, and one a pre-print undergoing peer-review) conclude that some might develop unstable orbits and, over a very long period of time, arch toward Earth.
But despite what several histrionic headlines have claimed, Earth is not at risk of one of these asteroids suddenly sneaking up on us and vaporizing a city. While some of these asteroids could be large enough to cause this sort of damage, there is no evidence whatsoever suggesting any of these Venus-pursuing asteroids are currently heading our way.Â
â€œI wouldnâ€™t say that â€¦

entry.title: Appendix: Detailed charts
entry.summary: The post Appendix: Detailed charts appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 169 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Centerâ€™s nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from April 28 to May 4, 2025. A total of 5,085 panelists responded out of 5,772 who were sampled, [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is made possible by The Pew Charitable Trusts. It is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Find related reports online at: pewresearch.org/science. Primary research teamÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Eileen Yam, Director, Science and Society ResearchAlec Tyson, Associate Director, Science and Society ResearchBrian Kennedy, Senior ResearcherGiancarlo Pasquini, Research AssociateEmma Kikuchi, [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Americansâ€™ interest in purchasing electric and hybrid vehicles
entry.summary: The electric vehicle market in the U.S. continues to expand, albeit at a slower pace than earlier in the decade. One-third of Americans say they would very or somewhat seriously consider purchasing an electric vehicle (EV) as their next vehicle. This is a slight uptick from last year (4 percentage points), but still down from [â€¦] The post 2. Americansâ€™ interest in purchasing electric and hybrid vehicles appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Views on Trump administration energy policies and priorities
entry.summary: The Trump administration has taken a number of actions to promote the development and use of fossil fuels and reduce support for renewable energy. This includes a push to increase drilling for oil and natural gas on federal lands and an executive order pausing approvals and permits for wind energy projects, including offshore wind. Where [â€¦] The post 1. Views on Trump administration energy policies and priorities appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Americansâ€™ Views on Energy at the Start of Trumpâ€™s Second Term
entry.summary: Americans have become less supportive of wind and solar power since the first Trump administration, a shift driven by declines in support among Republicans. The post Americansâ€™ Views on Energy at the Start of Trumpâ€™s Second Term appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.summary: Investigate Europe (IE), a network of cross-border journalists from across Europe, is looking for a Managing Director to join its team. In this pivotal role, you will lead our fundraising strategy, supervise strong financial management, and oversee the daily operations of a growing cross-border journalism organisation. This is a co-directorship role, managing the organisation alongside [â€¦]

entry.summary: The UNâ€™s top disarmament official has welcomed signs of increased cooperation from Syriaâ€™s interim authorities in efforts to eliminate the countryâ€™s chemical weapons once and for all, as preparations move forward for a third round of inspections by international experts.

entry.title: AIDS still killing one person every minute as funding cuts stall progress
entry.summary: AIDS-related deaths have dropped to their lowest level since 2004, but progress remains precarious, with the disease still claiming one life every minute. The impact of funding cuts is severe, causing widespread disruption to HIV services and threatening hard-won gains.

entry.summary: As hostilities rage in Sudan, access constraints and devastating funding cuts are isolating rape survivors and pregnant women from essential health services, the UN sexual and reproductive health agency UNFPA said on Thursday.

entry.title: Number of aid workers killed in Gaza conflict, highest in UN history: Guterres
entry.summary: The United Nations paid tribute on Thursday to the 168 staff members who lost their lives in 2024. They include 126 personnel killed in Gaza, all but one of whom served with the UN agency that assists Palestine refugees, UNRWA.

entry.summary: The lack of food entering Gaza caused by ongoing Israeli aid restrictions is leaving increasing numbers of Palestinians â€œvulnerable to starvationâ€, with daily energy intake now well below what a human body needs to survive, the UN warned on Thursday.

entry.title: From Sharing One Typewriter to Toppling a Corrupt President: How PCIJ Has Reshaped Watchdog Reporting in the Philippines
entry.summary: The Philippine Center for Investigative Journalism, a GIJN founding member, has grown from a one-room news startup 36 years ago to a seminal force for watchdog reporting.

entry.title: Niassa was conservation paradise. Then ISIS attacked.
entry.summary: Just after 7 p.m. on the evening of April 29, conservation ecologist Colleen Begg was having dinner with her husband, Keith, and their two teenage children when her phone beeped with a WhatsApp message: The Mariri Environmental Centre she had founded in Mozambiqueâ€™s Niassa Special Reserve had been attacked by terrorists. Two thousand people from a nearby village had fled into the bush. Begg spent a sleepless night organizing rescue efforts, but by morning she confronted a grim reality. Five of the ranger scouts on her team were missing, and a conservation dream she and Keith had spent more than 20 years nurturing was on the brink of collapse. The reserve is one of the last refuges for the critically endangered African wild dog, with some 300 of them roaming Niassaâ€™s plains. The dâ€¦

entry.title: Sinful. Poisonous. Stinky? How tomatoes overcame a wicked history
entry.summary:
Once called the "poison apple," tomatoes were thought to be supernatural and sinfulâ€”especially because of their red color. Tomatoes were reviled for centuriesâ€”so how did we come to embrace them? This small New Jersey town claims to have played a major role.
While Salem, Massachusetts gets all the hype for its infamous 1692 witch trials, thereâ€™s another city called Salemâ€”this time in New Jerseyâ€”thatâ€™s tied to a rather legendary tale where tomatoes were the enemy.
(Witch hunts were common in the 17th century. Hereâ€™s what made Salem infamous.)
There are many myths and legends about how the tomato was once seen as the so-called â€œpoison apple,â€ but how it lost its evil reputation and became a beloved piece of produce is a complicated story. According to historian Andrew F. Smâ€¦

entry.title: These sky-high climbing routes are popping up in U.S. cities
entry.summary:
These climbing routes can be found throughout Europe, and now they can be found inâ€”or nearâ€”U.S. cities, too. Once reserved for mountain towns, iron-rung climbing courses called via ferratas are showing up in places like Columbus, Ohio. Hereâ€™s where else to try one.
You may not expect to find a 100-foot-tall limestone climbing course within minutes of a bustling city center, but thatâ€™s exactly whatâ€™s on offer at Quarry Trails Metro Park in Columbus, Ohioâ€”home to the first urban via ferrata in the country.Â
Via ferratas are a combination of a ropes course and rock climbing. Harness-clad adventurers climb up and across sheer rock faces using iron rungs, steel cables, and vertiginous swinging bridges. The concept makes sky-high rock scaling feasible for those who lack technical roâ€¦

entry.title: The best places to stay at Joshua Tree National Park
entry.summary:
During its long tenure as a national monument (1936-1994), Joshua TreeÂ was largely a do-it-yourself park where visitors had to fend for themselves, especially when it came to accommodation.Â
Park brochures at that time explicitly stated, â€œNeither meals nor lodging are available in the Monument.â€ Campgrounds didnâ€™t appear until the 1950s and they were very primitive, little more than a patch of sand with a picnic table.Â
The turning point was Joshua Tree getting upgraded to national park status in 1994. Ever since, the accommodation situation has continued to improve. Camping is still the only way to sleep inside the park. But the range of overnight options in the gateway towns of Yucca Valley, Joshua Tree, and Twentynine Palms has undergone a quantum leap.Â Â Â Â
(Everything yoâ€¦

entry.title: Why three-toed sloths risk their lives to help moths
entry.summary:
For centuries, people encountering sloths for the first time have reacted by ridiculing them. In 1526, Spanish conquistadorÂ Gonzalo FernÃ¡ndez de Oviedo y ValdÃ©sÂ wrote that the sloths heâ€™d seen in the American tropics were â€œugly,â€ â€œuseless,â€ and â€œthe stupidest animal that can be found in the world.â€ In 1749, French naturalist Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte de Buffon, called themÂ â€œthe lowest form of existenceâ€ and judged that â€œone more defect would have made their lives impossible.â€
Harsh words about a creature thatâ€™s survivedÂ for at least 50 million years.Â Sloths have moth buddies who live with themThe more moths a sloth has, the more algae it has in its fur. In turn, the algae camouflages the sloth. Yes, sloths have poor hearing and eyesight,Â and they're slowâ€”the slowest mammâ€¦

entry.title: 8 family-friendly things to do in Joshua Tree
entry.summary:
Keeping kids engaged and entertained at Joshua Tree National Park is often a matter of simple pleasures like camping in the desert, watching the heavens through a microscope, or scrambling between giant boulders at Skull Rock, Heart Rock, and other stony outcrops.Â Here are 10 things to do in Joshua Tree with kids.
Hiking is one of the easiest activities for families to dive into. Unless youâ€™re going to hike at dusk or dawn, itâ€™s advisable to avoid marching the kids through the parkâ€™s triple-digit summer heat. Be sure to sync the hikeâ€™s length and difficulty level with their age and trekking experience.Â
Among the parkâ€™s kid-friendly short hikes are Cholla Cactus Garden, the Oasis of Mara, Keys View with its mile-high panoramic views of the Coachella Valley, the slot canyons of â€¦

entry.title: Everything to know about Joshua Tree National Park
entry.summary:
Southern California's Joshua Tree National Park is best known for its iconic flora. The park straddles the Colorado Desert and the Mojave Desert, and features Keys View, which overlooks the famed Coachella Valleyâ€”but there's much more to explore. Arid low desert and vegetated high desert meet in this beloved natural gem, offering visitors stunning vistas and rewarding hikes.
Joshua Tree National Park is often described as an out-of-this-world experience or healing for oneâ€™s soul, says Donovan Smith, the parkâ€™s public information officer. â€œWith blue sunny skies almost year-round, the wide-open vistas allow the visitor to experience the true vastness of the landscape from almost anywhere in the park. Itâ€™s an extraordinary place to connect with the beauty and reliance nature has to ofâ€¦

entry.title: A complete guide to hiking in Joshua Tree National Park
entry.summary:
Like many national parks, Joshua Tree National Park offers aÂ wide range of trailsÂ at all levels of hiking expertise and ability. No matter which route you choose or time of year you decide to visit, always remember that this national park is a desert.
Sunscreen, a hat, ample water, and a flashlight for night hikes are required even on shorter hikes. On longer jaunts, pack energy snacks, and a portable first-aid kit in case you have an unexpected run-in with a cactus or wildlife. Due to the lack of reliable cell phone service in the park, download your hiking route to GPS before setting off.
Joshua Tree National ParkÂ is utterly oppressive during the summer when midday temperatures frequently hover above 100Â°F. Winter means cooler days (around 60Â°F), freezing nights, and the â€¦
